EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the Freshpoint Southern California facility.  Since the facility does not maintain an internal Emergency Response Team, the policy is based on Cal-OSHAs requirements for Emergency Action Plan (CCR Title 8, Section 3220).  The Emergency Action Plan is detailed in the Emergency Planning & Response section of the PSM / RMP documents which is maintained by the Facility Maintenance Manager at the facility.

This program contains procedures detailing how the facility will respond to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies such as fires, earthquakes, power outages, etc.  This program has been coordinated with the local emergency service agencies including: the City of Industry Fire Department, Los Angeles County Fire Department + HazMat Team, and the local emergency management services agency.

The facilitys Emergency Action Plan Policy includes the following elements:

  --  Key Facility Personnel and Responsibilities
  --  Outside Agency Notification Contact Information
  --  Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments
  --  First Aid Procedures
  --  Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
  --  Evacuation Plans + Assembly Areas
  --  Description for Handling Small Ammonia Releases
  --  Details of Outside Assistance Available 
  --  Incident Command System
  --  Initial and Refresher Training


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Freshpoint Southern California is committed to the safety of employees, contractors/guests/visitors, as well as neighbors.  Continual evaluations of risks associated with the ammonia systems by in-house personnel as well as outside risk management professionals help to limit the possibility of unintended impacts associated with ammonia.

frigeration systems.  Safety features include ammonia leak detectors in the machinery room and cold storage zones, microprocessor controlled compressors with automatic alarms + trips, ASME certified pressure vessels, and emergency stop controls.

The majority of the ammonia inventory is centrally located in the machine room vessels and equipment.  All pressure-rated vessels are equipped with mechanical pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation and vent to a water diffusion tank that is available to neutralize high pressure ammonia.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through stages of liquid to vapor to liquid, similar to the refrigerant in a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks are noted and repaired immediately.

Continued safety improvement for the ammonia refrigeration system is a top priority for Freshpoint Southern California.  The management plan, internal audits, Process Hazard Analysis studies, as well as our risk management policies are monitored and updated as appropriate to ensure that all elements of our PSM / RMP program remain accurate and complete.

The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 

--  On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
--  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

Programs developed for the PSM / RMP programs include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, pre-startup safety review, standard operating procedures, training, management of change, mechanical integrity (inspections / testing / maintenance), hot work permit, contractor management, and incident investigation.  To help coordinate the various elements of the program, a management system has been established that defines responsible parties at the facility for each element of the facilitys PSM / RMP program.  The facility utilizes the services of a local professional refrigeration contractor for routine inspections / testing / maintenance activities, as well as service calls.  The preventative maintenance program is based on manufacturer recommendations, as well as industry standards and guidelines.

In the event of an accidental ammonia release, the emergency response plan is coordinated with the local emergency planning commission (LEPC) and the local fire house  Los Angeles County Fire Department Station 87.  The ultimate goal for Freshpoint Southern Californias PSM / RMP plan is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, injuries / illnesses, and to avoid adverse impacts to the environment.  These programs enable our facility to operate a refrigeration system safely because they are based on the rules, procedures, and guidelines that govern the ammonia refrigeration system, as well as the broader ammonia refrigeration industry throughout the country.

The Freshpoint Southern California ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  The Freshpoint Southern California facility, including the ammonia system, was designed and constructed in accordance with the recognized industry codes and standards, which specifically outline requirements for the design and operation of ammonia re

ssure relief valves are replaced on a five year frequency.  Ammonia leak detectors are calibrated semi-annually and trigger local audible + visual alarms for facility personnel.

Refrigeration process equipment at the facility operates continuously based on temperature readings in the warehouse.  The compressors and condensers cycle on and off to address system heat load demands during operation.  The refrigeration machinery room houses the compressors, recirculator and accumulator vessels, and auxiliary components, while the condenser is located on a raised platform outside.  Evaporators are located in various cold storage and dock rooms throughout the building.

Ammonia is used as the primary refrigerant, which means it is used as a vehicle to move heat from cold storage zones to the outside atmosphere.  When heat is absorbed by the liquid ammonia, it vaporizes (changes phase), and is then compressed by the compressors.  The resulting high pressure ammonia vapor is routed to the condensers, where fans and sprayed water are used to reject latent heat in the ammonia vapor, causing it to condense to a liquid.

Multiple auxiliary systems are in place to support the operational and safety requirements of the ammonia system including:  ammonia leak detection, auto purger to remove non-condensible gasses, pressure relief system, refrigeration control system, and a water diffusion tank that neutralizes any ammonia vapor vented through a pressure relief valve.  An Emergency Refrigerant Control Box is also available and can be used to reduce pressures on the high pressure side of the system.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Freshpoint Southern California facility (including the ammonia refrigeration system) was commissioned in 2007.  The facility is located approximately 1.8 miles east of Interstate 605 freeway, and approximately 1.5 miles north of CA State Highway 60, and just north of Valley Boulevard.

Freshpoint Southern California is a cold storage logistics facility that receives, sorts, and distributes cold food products.  The refrigeration requirements are serviced by an industrial refrigeration system that utilizes anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant.  The maximum intended inventory of ammonia at the facility is approximately 12,000 pounds.

The accidental release prevention program starts with good operating and safe work practices.  All ammonia process equipment, piping, and valves are inspected and maintained on a regular schedule by a professional refrigeration contractor in accordance with manufacturer and industry recommendations.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Freshpoint Southern California recognizes the facilitys responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  Freshpoint Southern California is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program.  This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration equipment at Freshpoint Southern California in the City of Industry, California.

It is Freshpoint Southern Californias policy to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  To accomplish the companys goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established safety programs that enable facility personnel to: maximize safety performance, reduce risks of handling ammonia and other potentially hazardous substances, and prepare facility personnel to address emergency situations as they might arise.

The Freshpoint facility draws from decades of company (including corporate) experience and expertise, as well as resources of external consultants, to ensure that the appropriate mitigation measures have been identified and are implemented.  The commitment to safety shows in the minimal accident history at the facility.

One of the activities associated with the facilitys safety program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals), and EPAs Risk Management Program regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention), as well as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program.
